author: yutazzz
title: dRep improvement and onboarding
description: How do you achieve "(1) diverse and many dRep participation + (2) easy and proper voter delegation?"

f6_assessments.q0: I welcome the proposer’s pro-active approach to the introduction of dReps and his attention to the importance of a community-led effort to better define and contribute to the role of future dReps. The proposer has clearly and succinctly articulated the importance of the challenge – and I think that is a good way of doing it. The proposer states that the challenge wants to avoid centralization by promoting diversity of dReps and to promote higher voter delegation in order to ensure the system is functional. Great insight there. The definition of success is a bit less convincing to me as it includes some metrics such as 200+ dReps from 100+ countries have participated – although it is currently difficult to predict is that achievable and whether a key measure of decentralization should be the national affiliation of dReps (although it is one of many valid measures). Fortunately, in the challenge brief, the proposer also includes other metrics about the diversity of dReps. As regards the second definition of success – I presume that ‘50%+ of the voters are voting “carefully”’ means that voters are delegating their votes to dReps or voting directly, however – this might be clarified a bit, if this challenge proposal is not accepted this round and is resubmitted. This challenge is important for realizing Cardano’s mission and is perfectly aligned with the Fund 9 goals 1, 3 and 4.
f6_assessments.q1: I would commend the proposer of this challenge for revising the budget of this challenge setting proposal downwards from the $150,000 that was set in Fund 9 to a smaller amount of ADA100,000 in Fund 10 (if this proposal is accepted).The proposer has himself explained that the number of proposals submitted to this challenge (in the ongoing Fund 9) is “relatively lower than the other categories”. This would be expected as this is a relatively niche category – so that doesn’t surprise me. However, it does indicate that it might be too early to do a repeat of the same challenge, if interest for the previous challenge was relatively lower. Furthermore, the dReps system has yet to be launched and there is no indication that the previous challenge for dRep improvement and onboarding will not provide sufficient results. The previous challenge had a larger budget and is attracting proposals. Hence, it might be overkill to launch a back-to-back challenge to achieve something that might be resolved with the first challenge. For this reason, I am a bit concerned whether the community will have the capacity of addressing this challenge – if the previous challenge already proves to be successful and it results in diverse dRep participation.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposed metrics seem good, but might also be improved by including other metrics of diversity – which are not simply geographical or biological or societal. We would probably also need dReps with technical abilities and those with other types of abilities, dReps who have experience as builders in Cardano and dReps who have experience as end users of Cardano. Some metrics seem more general like “How many dReps were onboarded?” Also, the timeline of the challenge implementation will  probably coincide and overlap in great measure with the dRep onboarding process and the previous Fund 9 dRep challenge, making it very complicated to verify whether this challenge will have the desired effect or whether it is the effect of the previous  challenge for dReps – or whether it was the natural outcome of a well-organized dRep onboarding process.

f6_assessments.q0:
Catalyst is already the largest decentralized innovation fund in the world, but for Cardano to have a functional, highly representative and decentralized governance layer, it is important that we increase the level of community participation in the voting stages.

https://iohk.io/en/blog/posts/2021/07/08/introducing-the-catalyst-circle/

The concept of dReps and vote delegation is a good option to increase the number of unique wallet votes per proposal and challenge setting, making the voting process more diluted and distributed among the community, so this challenge is important to improve Catalyst and Cardano.

There is a risk of centralization, because if there are few dReps or dReps with a lot of delegated voting power, this can make the decision in the votes end up more centralized in popular dReps, but the challenge setting took into account this problem by proposing a large amount of dReps and a geographic distribution in order to dilute this influence.

This challenge setting is in line with items 1 and 4 of the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals mentioned in the Proposal Assessor Guide.
f6_assessments.q1:
This challenge is present in the current Fund 9, but there was no significant demand from the community, as the challenge setting proposer himself mentions, this brings less confidence that the community has the capacity and/or interest in creating proposals on this topic.

The budget has been slightly reduced to reflect the demand seen at Fund9.
f6_assessments.q2:
Two definitions of success were defined. The first is bold, relevant, but I don't think it's realistic. Achieving 200+ dReps in over 100 countries with the budget available in this challenge setting is extremely optimistic to say the least. If this objective is achieved, it would have to be measured how many dReps were onboarded due to proposals resulting from this challenge and how many dReps were onboarded outside the challenge, which would be something non-trivial.

The second definition of success is unclear, how do you define whether more than half of voters are voting carefully? There is no rationale that better explains this definition, so the second definition of success is not practical or easy to measure.

The challenge setting established a period of time for gauging the definition of success, which is positive.

The proposed key metrics are appropriate to the context of the challenge, as they allow us to assess the number of voters and dReps, the diversity of dReps and the quality/precision so that the relationship between voter and dRep is efficient and positive.

f6_assessments.q0:
dReps in it's earliest iteration seeks to tackle the lack of voter participation. Though at the same time, dReps provides a window for minorities, in terms of influence, in terms of recognition, in terms of voting power to have a fighting change to get their message across. At this current moment, there is a rumbling from minorities  -with the above 3 (three) containers- , whom feel they will never get voted on.

Due to perhaps lack of writing skills, due to lack of recognized proposer identity, due to just not being a forcefully active community. I use forcefully for not all individuals are extroverts whom are comfortable in conveying and in partaking English discourse. At it's current state Project Catalyst is not fully inclusive, it still largely caters to the Western Hemisphere.

dReps can potentially change that by being that trusted individual from a local community who has recognition in the Global Cardano community. By having a "champion", it is hoped that minorities will have a better chance of getting votes. We need dReps to truly become decentralized and inclusive. This jostling and competition for attention for those who do not like to seek attention detracts from potentially a proposal that has strong merits.
f6_assessments.q1:
Although Project Catalyst is not fully inclusive, the ambers of diversity is there. There are a number of local community representatives whom have already build a reputation in the global Cardano community. There are trusted individuals from across Africa, across Asia, across Latin America and by having dReps now, it would assist so many voters to vote on worthy proposals based on the merit of the goal they seek to achieve. Not only on the merit of a high recognized individual or group, but on quality of the proposal and the trustworthiness of the proposer whom have been vetted by their local dReps.

We do have PA's and vPA's, but there are elements of these two roles that can be manipulated for the benefit of certain individuals or groups. dReps has the potential to negate judgement by PA's and vPA's by having a familiar face on a proposal. Although one can still indeed manipulate, the stakes are higher for dReps are not anonymous and are vetted by IOG. It is a position that we as a community should explore for the potential inclusive and fairness it brings, outweighs the potential manipulative bad actors.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is a balance between metrics success and vision fulfilment. Though the success criteria could have been more elaborated. For an example ; through dReps the growth of proposal approval from minority groups sees an improvement by 75% or perhaps through dReps the diversity of funded proposals in terms of region represented sees an increase of 50% and etc.

At it's current state, success criteria only addresses dReps growth and voter growth. Although they are indeed the primary indicators of success intended, there is a larger collateral chain reaction that would have been informative if dwell more upon in this proposal. There is though a quick mentioning of something related which is the creation of tools to assess the validity of dReps choices. It unfortunately focuses on the tools to rate dReps performance and not on the actual results expected of from a dReps.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of this proposal is to improve the whole dRep process. dReps are community members to which other community members could delegate their vote for in Catalyst, therefore, this challenge proposal is directly related to improving the human processes related to Catalyst and very well aligned with Cardano’s mission for Fund 10. Besides that, the importance of the topic is also very high. Since Catalyst is going to be the future of Cardano’s governance, it is essential that it becomes as democratic as possible. Addressing the goals mentioned in the challenge proposal of increasing diversity of dReps, quantity, number of delegates and all other are essential to make the voting system as fair as possible. The alignment of this challenge proposal with Cardano’s goal is very high.
f6_assessments.q1: The budget of the challenge proposal is appropriate for its goal. 100k ADA to improve the process of dReps fits, in my opinion, not only what the community is able to come up with in regard to number of high-quality proposals submitted in it, and the requirement for improvements regarding dReps in general. It would make much sense to have a much higher budget than this, because the evolution needs to be slow to identify what’s working and what’s not to make the necessary adjustments along the way. Also, this challenge has already been approved once for Fund 9 and there have been 32 proposals submitted that time. This number is not that high, but we can see that the proposer probably paid attention to this information since they have decreased the challenge budget from $150k to 100k ADA this time, which can be maximum $100k. I believe this challenge is probably going to be successful and the community can use its budget in an effective manner.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs included in the proposal are very appropriate to measure its success. They cover diversity of dReps, quantity, number of delegates and the accuracy of choosing dReps and their evaluation about all proposals. The accuracy KPIs might be a bit difficult to measure since they are quite subjective since we don’t know exactly what a good dReps is, especially because it considers the dRep’s opinion after all, and the ease of assessing proposals by dReps. Overall, these KPIs are very well aligned with the challenge’s goals, and I believe the challenge team and the community won’t have much trouble verifying this challenge’s success in the future.

f6_assessments.q0:
I strongly disagree that this challenge is critical to achieve Cardano’s mission. The dRep initiative is the need of an hour for project catalyst as more and more proposals are being made, making the job tedious and time consuming for voters. Nevertheless, the dRep initiative, although it will tend to improve catalyst process, covers partially the 4 strategic goals of fund 9. 

There is no details given on if the dRep process will help Cardano get in open source direction with more onboarding of developers, which is point 2 of 4 point Fund 9 strategic goals. Additionally, this process is very specific to Catalyst (at least in the beginning) and hence does not cover point 3 of “Build real world solutions based on Cardano”. 

For instance: The total budget asked for is $100k, and this challenge can easily be converted to a proposal under miscellaneous settings. Therefore, this criticality is limited to achieving better human sensory and improved quality of the Catalyst process, and is just another experiment which may or may not improve the governance in Catalyst.

f6_assessments.q0: In March 2022, IOG introduced to the Project Catalyst community the concept of absolute liquid democracy, as well as a new role called "delegated representatives" which will give to the Cardano community the ability to delegate their voting power. This is completely optional and available to be changed for any model at any moment. They will be able to vote on Catalyst proposals, as well as on future changes to the Cardano protocol and approve Treasury transfers and associated policy. This challenge seeks to make the introduction of this innovation to the process as minimally centralized and dysfunctional as possible. I agree with this challenge as I see an alignment with Cardano's mission, as well as meeting one of the 4 strategic goals we have for the next fund.
f6_assessments.q1: As a result of the current fund, which has an allocated budget of $150,000 in ADA, the community responded with 25 proposals. While I would have expected a larger number of proposals that would confirm the community's capacity and willingness in this regard, I found an interesting variety of proposals that from my point of view contribute to an excellent introduction to the role. Additionally, it is important to note that the team responsible for preparing this proposal decided to reduce the requested budget to $100,000 ADA after analyzing the level of response from the community in this fund. I find this to be a wise decision, and I therefore strongly agree with this decision in terms of feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2: Although the description of success is excessively specific, I consider it appropriate considering the topic in question. It seems that the metrics presented are entirely appropriate, easy to measure, and are in a general enough format to allow for a healthy comparison between competing proposals. I would recommend to the challenge team that, as part of future catalyst cycles, a section should be included that describes the potential directions that the projects expected to be part of this challenge may take.

f6_assessments.q0:
DReps is a new concept which is soon to be implemented on Catalyst and it works on the concept of staking. In the case of staking, you stake your coins to an existing stakepool instead of creating you own pool and that stakepool mints blocks and participates in the network on behalf of you. Similarly in the case of catalyst voting, you can delegate your voting power to these Dreps and they will will be taking part in the voting process on behalf of you. The main reason to implement such a concept was lower turnout of voters for Catalyst (around 20% of total holders). Another problem with voting process is that there are hundreds of proposals in every fund and it is not feasible to expect voters to read all these proposals before voting and this results in random voting by the Voters.
***
The implementation of the Dreps in itself poses some challenges as being a very new concept, the biggest task would be to create awareness around it. Without many people participating as Dreps, the process will become centralized. Also without easy and proper voter delegation, it may become dysfunctional.  This challenge will seek from proposers to create the proposals which will help in diversification and should result in dRep participation from all over the world and easy and proper voter delegation process to make it function efficiently.
***
This challenge perfectly aligns with Cardano's mission and it will help in making the Governance process more efficient and decentralized.

f6_assessments.q0: For Fund-9, the 1. Strategic Goal is to "prepare a group of people willing and able to make contributions to the ecosystem". This could mean enabling community members active in Catalyst to become part-time or full-time funded by submitting governance proposals fund-to-fund or alternatively some sort of perpetual funding, term funding, or payroll. The dRep role will entail voting on behalf of "delegators" in a yet to be implemented liquid democracy experiment that forms part of the coming of the Voltaire Era. Without expanding or curtailing the scope intended for the role, this proposed challenge setting simply encourages improvements to ensure dReps are diverse, and vote responsibly, for example without bias, not taking excessive risk, being mindful of trends and the web3 space as a whole. In this regard, the challenge aligns very well with the mission of Cardano and in my opinion adds a lot of value to Catalyst - not just by preparing the dRep cohort, but also by ensuring their service for the entire ecosystem for future funds.

With currently rolled out workshops for the first cohort of dReps, the community will be in a much better position to address the challenge in Fund-10. This combination of factors makes me confident that the community would benefit from the challenge and it sufficiently well equipped to fulfil it to its potential.
f6_assessments.q2: The challenge setting proposal offers possible metrics to measure its success in achieving diversity and quality of future dRep cohorts. It also asks meaningful questions how voter participation can be increased and the dRep role could evolve to create improvements for the current structure of Catalyst. Despite using bullet points, the success criteria section is conversational. By separating statements and statistics from goals and metrics, the proposal could have achieved even better clarity. I agree that criteria are set correctly. It should be possible to quantify or qualitatively assess all the possible metrics and KPIs suggested.
